{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3301695,"name":"","username":"theVerySharpFlat","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/848f3c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-02-04T20:40:17.622Z","cooked":"

Our team has a library and season code which contains a source copy of the library (because vendordeps and git submodules are a PITB to deal with during season).

The library essentially provides utility classes that wrap around motorcontroller APIs and control drivetrains and was developed over the course of the last two years during both season and offseason.

As the code has been public since the first commit, it seems to me that this is not in violation of R303. However, it concerns me that we are in violation of example 2

Example 2: A team developed an omni-directional drive system for the 2019 competition. In July 2019 they refined and improved the
control software, written in C++, to add more precision and capabilities. They decided to use a similar system for the CRESCENDO competition. They copied large sections of unmodified code over into the
control software of the new
ROBOT, also written in C++. This would be a violation of the schedule constraint and is not allowed.

Of course, our library has slightly changed during this season as we port it to the 2024 versions of vendor APIs.

TLDR; QUESTION: If I copy my (public) library into my 2024 source tree with little modification, is that in violation of R303?

You’re fine.

At least as far as I am concerned, none of us on here can really speak in an official capacity.

You would have to run into a crazy rules lawyer for this to even be slightly in a gray area.

Just my $0.02

Since your code is and has been public, it falls under example 4, not example 2.

Example 4: A different team develops a similar solution during the fall and plans to use the developed software on their competition ROBOT. After completing the software, they post it in a generally accessible public forum and make the code available to all teams. Because they have made their software publicly available before Kickoff, they can use it on their ROBOT.

Though it doesn’t explicitly state that example 2 is a team that never published the code, so it’s not exactly a helpful clarification.

Thanks, Mr. Stratis! As @Amicus1 has pointed out, my confusion was that my code was compliant with some examples (such as number 4, which you indicated) but not others if we assume that code is implicitly public (which I assumed, since, I suppose, I’m a rabid FOSS activist )
